title: 113_s2417
content: The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" may impose a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" may impose a lifetime ban on former members of Congress from lobbying after leaving office. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" may impose a lifetime ban on former members of Congress from lobbying after leaving office. Any attempt by a former Senator, Member, or elected official to influence current members of Congress on behalf of someone else may result in punishment as specified in the law. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the title 18 of the United States Code regarding staff and elected officers of the Senate. SEC. 3 amends section 207(e) of title 18, United States Code, increasing the time limit to 6 years. SEC. 4 focuses on improving the reporting of lobbyists' activities. Section 6 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to create a joint lobbyist disclosure Internet database called lobbyists.gov for public information. $100,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2015. Any person who is a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal cannot be hired by a Member or committee of Congress within 6 years of leaving their position if they had substantial lobbying contact. A waiver can be granted by the Committee on Ethics or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct based on a compelling national need. When determining if a registered lobbyist or foreign agent had substantial lobbying contact, Congress considers if the contacts related to pending legislation, earmarks, coordination of meetings, presentations to staff, or fundraising beyond personal contributions. Social contacts with Congress are excluded. The definition of substantial lobbying contacts includes interactions related to pending legislation, earmarks, coordination of meetings, presentations to staff, or fundraising beyond personal contributions. Simple social contacts with Congress members or staff do not count as substantial lobbying contacts. SEC. 6A. REPORTING BY SUBSTANTIAL LOBBYING ENTITIES. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to include reporting requirements for substantial lobbying entities. Substantial lobbying entities must annually report to the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate any employees, contractors, or consultants who are former members of Congress or congressional staff meeting specific criteria. The filing required by this section for substantial lobbying entities must include a brief job description of employees, contractors, or consultants who are former members of Congress or congressional staff meeting specific criteria. The filing required for substantial lobbying entities must include a brief job description of employees, contractors, or consultants, and an explanation of their work experience. The Joint website lobbyists.gov will have a searchable database for qualifying individuals. The Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate will provide filings of substantial lobbying entities to the District of Columbia United States Attorney for oversight. Substantial lobbying entity refers to an incorporated entity that employs individuals for lobbying activities. The term "substantial lobbying entity" is defined as an incorporated entity that employs more than 3 federally registered lobbyists during a filing period. SEC. 7 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to increase penalties from $200,000 to $500,000.
